docs.title: Linux Hacker Notes
docs.text:
Welcome to my personal collection of Linux notes, commands, projects, and learning resources.

This site serves as a knowledge base for my journey through different Linux distributions, command-line tools, and system administration techniques.

docs.title: Site Sections
docs.text:
• Commands: Reference guide for Linux commands and their usage
  • Projects: Linux-based projects I'm working on
  • Lessons: Tutorials and lessons learned
  • Scripts: Useful scripts for automation and system management
  • Distributions: Notes on different Linux distributions
  • Journal: My learning journal
  • Thoughts: Ideas and concepts related to Linux

docs.title: About This Site
docs.text: This site is built with MkDocs and hosted on GitHub Pages. It's designed to be a living document that grows as I learn more about Linux.

docs.text:

docs.title: Common Commands
docs.text: Command Description Example ls List directory contents ls -la cd Change directory cd /etc grep Search for patterns grep "error" /var/log/syslog find Search for files find / -name "*.conf" ps Report process status ps aux

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
• Use man [command] to view the manual page for a command
  • Use tab completion to save time typing commands and paths
  • Use history to view previously executed commands

docs.title: 2024-05-01: Getting Started with MkDocs
docs.text:
Today I set up MkDocs for my Linux Hacker Notes site. The process was straightforward:

  1. Created the basic directory structure
  2. Set up the configuration file
  3. Added GitHub Actions for automatic deployment
  4. Started adding content to the site

I'm excited to see how this site evolves as I continue learning about Linux.

docs.title: Scripts
docs.text: This section contains useful scripts for Linux system administration and automation.

docs.title: Backup Scripts
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
# Simple backup script
BACKUP_DIR="/backup"
SOURCE_DIR="/home/user/documents"
DATE=$(date +%Y-%m-%d)

mkdir -p $BACKUP_DIR
tar -czf $BACKUP_DIR/backup-$DATE.tar.gz $SOURCE_DIR
echo "Backup completed: $BACKUP_DIR/backup-$DATE.tar.gz"
